clinical_study.brief_title: Specimen X-Rays of Removed Axillary Lymph Nodes to Guide Pathological Sampling
clinical_study.official_title: Specimen X-Rays of Removed Axillary Lymph Nodes to Guide Pathological Sampling (GPS)

brief_summary.textblock: X-ray mapping of sentinel lymph nodes and/or axillary tissue will assist pathologists in their ability to identify the number and location of lymph nodes as well as more accurately section lymph nodes contained in surgical specimens.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Within the first 30 minutes after specimen is removed from the body
primary_outcome.description: To determine if plain x-ray films obtained from the sentinel node/axillary dissection specimen can facilitate the identification of the lymph nodes and increase the average number of lymph nodes recovered by the pathologist.

primary_outcome.measure: Identification of affected area in node
primary_outcome.time_frame: Within the first 30 minutes after specimen is removed from the body
primary_outcome.description: To determine whether plain x-ray films obtained from the sentinel node/axillary dissection specimen can help direct the pathologist to the correct part of the node (the portion containing disease) to sample.

arm_group.description: After nodes are removed they are taken to radiology to be x-rayed

intervention.description: surgical specimen taken to radiology and contents x-rayed

study_pop.textblock: Males or females of all races and ethnicities, must be equal to or greater than 18 years of age, scheduled for breast cancer surgery that includes sentinel node biopsy and/or axillary dissection

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Males or females of all races and ethnicities
- ≥ 18 years of age
- Must be scheduled for breast cancer surgery which includes a sentinel lymph node biopsy and/or axillary dissection
Exclusion Criteria:
• Any person whose final pathology could be compromised in any way by the X-ray procedure

facility.name: University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences

Sensitivity of axillary specimen x-ray to predict nodal count and positivity. Ann Surg Oncol. 2011 Oct;18(11):3181-6. doi: 10.1245/s10434-011-1959-x. Epub 2011 Aug 23.

clinical_study.keyword: X-ray identification of nodes in a surgical specimen
